sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1: Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the complete combustion of methane gas (CH4(g)) at constant pressure, given the balanced equation: CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l). The standard enthalpies of formation of CO2(g), H2O(l), and CH4(g) are -393.5 kJ/mol, -285.8 kJ/mol, and -74.8 kJ/mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the complete combustion of methane gas, we can use the following formula:

ΔH° = Σ ΔH°f(products) - Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

where ΔH° is the standard enthalpy change, and ΔH°f is the standard enthalpy of formation.

For the given balanced equation:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

The standard enthalpies of formation are:

ΔH°f(CH4(g)) = -74.8 kJ/mol
ΔH°f(O2(g)) = 0 kJ/mol (since O2 is in its standard state)
ΔH°f(CO2(g)) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔH°f(H2O(l)) = -285.8 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH° = [1 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.8 kJ/mol) + 2 × 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH° = (-393.5 - 2 × 285.8 + 74.8) kJ/mol

ΔH° = (-393.5 - 571.6 + 74.8) kJ/mol

ΔH° = (-964.3 + 74.8) kJ/mol

ΔH° = -889.5 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the complete combustion of methane gas at constant pressure is -889.5 kJ/mol.
